field_edited_text.value:
Existing Conditions

Industrial Activity: 57 industries are
located in Fairfield: 12 are involved in pet-
roleum storage and refining, 10 in chemical
manufacturing, and 24 are involved in
commodity storage and distribution. Practi-
cally all the rest are engaged in metal
manufacture and fabrication, shipbuilding
and repair, and general manufacturing.

*Chemical Manufacture - Most of Fair-
field’s 10 chemical manufacturers are
located south of the Harbor Tunnel
Thruway crossing. The three largest
firms are FMC Corp., proﬁ'ucer of
organic chemicals and pesticides, with
395 employees; Conoco Chemicals,
maker of detergents and alkalytes, with
182 employees; and Alcolac Corp.,
manufacturer of detergents, with 160
employees.

*Petroleum Storage and Refining - Pet-
roleum companies maintain two types
of operations in Fairfield: tank farms
and asphalt refineries. Fairfield contains
the largest concentration of tank farms
of any area on the Baltimore harbor.
Oil storage facilities, maintained by
eight oil companies, occupy over 300
acres in Fairfield. The tanks store both
light fuels (gasoline, home heating oil,
kerosene, and jet fuel) which can be
piped into the area through the Colon-
ial Pipeline and heavy fuels (used in
manufacturing processes and power
plants) which are too thick to be
moved by pipeline and must be ship-
ped by barge. In addition to the tank
farms, Fairfield contains three asphalt
plants which serve a regional market.
Crude oil used in asphalt production is
brought to these plants by barge or
ship while the asphalt is distributed by
truck or rail.

*Metals Manufacture and Fabrication -
Seven firms engage in metal fabrica-
tion. The largest, Bethlehem Steel’s
Buffalo Tank Division, employs 175
persons in the production of steel
tanks ranging from fuel tanks used by
gasoline stations to nuclear reactor
shields. Another firm, American Seam-
less Tubing Corp., was acquired by
Copperweld, Inc. and is expected to
expand from 60 to 200 employees:
American Seamless produces drill bits
and equipment for drilling gas and oil
wells.

*Shipbuilding and Repairing - The
largest employer in Fairfield for a
number of years was the Maryland
Shipbuilding and Drydock Company at
its Frankfurst Avenue Facility. Maryland
Shipbuilding and Drydock announced
in 1984 that it was closing its operation.

The facility is currently for sale. Fair-
field’s other ship repair firm is the
American Dredging Company which
specializes in the maintenance of
dredging vessels. It employs 17
persons.

*Commodity Storage and Distribution -

Three distinct categories of commodi-
ties are stored and distributed at Fair-
field facilities.

General Merchandise. Low rents and
excellent transportation have made
Fairfield a favorite location for storing
or warehousing a wide variety of pro-
ducts including automobiles, lumber,
steel, and plastics. The largest storage
operation is the Hobelmann Corp.,
which imports and stores automobiles
at its Fairfield facility.

Many small firms lease space in the
long row of warehouses operated by
Harris Heller Terminals between Curtis
and Pennington Avenues and in the
Empire Industrial Center on Benbhill
Avenue.

Solid Bulk Commodities. Three com-
panies store ore and coal in Fairfield.
The CSX Railroad runs both an ore
import yard and a coal export yard on
Curtis Bay. The Island Creek Co. oper-
ates a coal storage and export facility at
Curtis Bay. Overflow at the ore import
facility is stored by the Joseph Hock
Co. at its yard on Northbridge Avenue.

Liquid Bulk Commodities. Besides pet-
roleum, two other liquid commodities
are stored and distributed in Fairfield.
Skyline Terminals, acquired in 1981 by
W.R. Grace Co., handles commodities
for the food and chemical processing
industries. Allied Chemical operates a
terminal which receives chemicals
shipped by barge.

*General Manufacturing - Two sizeable

brick manufacturers operate plants in
Fairfield. Harbison-Walker Refractories
on Patapsco Avenue and General
Refractories on Chesapeake Avenue.

Residential Areas: Surrounded by Fair-
field’s heavy industry are three residential
communities.

*Old Fairfield - This cluster of homes

dates back to the turn of the century
when housing was often built on
industiral land. Currently, this small
black community of about 200 resi-
dents is characterized by industrial
encroachment, unpaved or deterio-
rated streets, vacant houses and lots,
poor street lighting and limited public
transportation. In 1977 the City
extended a sewer line into the area to
service the scattered homes. However,
the operations of a number of the sur-

56

rounding industries, heavily impact the
residents in this area, which has been
industrially zoned since 1931. Residents
who wish to leave the area may
request the City to purchase their
homes and for assistance in relocation.

*Fairfield Homes - Built during World

War Il to house workers for Fairfield’s
wartime industries, Fairfield Homes was
converted to public housing after the
war. Today Fairfield Homes houses
1,002 residents. Bordered north and
south by streets with heavy truck traffic
and separated from the nearest shop-
ping areas by industry and a major
railyard, the community is subject to
high levels of noise and dust. There is
also the difficult and dangerous situa-
tion of having to cross railroad tracks
and highways to reach the nearest
commerical area. In an effort-to
upgrade the community facilities, the
recreation center has been improved
and the playground rebuilt with a“
special grant from the federal Coastal
Energy Impact Program.

*Wagner’s Point - This three-block long,

working class community of 255 resi-
dents originated as housing for
employees of nearby industry.
Bordered on one side by a heavily-
used industrial road and on the other
side by tank farms, Wagner’s Point
consists of approximately 85 row-
houses. The streets in the community
are in generally good repair and the
City maintains a small playground.

Besides the three communities on the
peninsula itself, two others — Brooklyn
and Curtis Bay — border Fairfield on
the northwest and west respectively.
